page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 90: Line 90:
[[File:Tahrir Square on May 27 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 27 May 2011]]
[[File:Tahrir Square on May 27 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 27 May 2011]]
â
On May 24, 2011, it was announced that Egypt's ousted President Hosni Mubarak and his two sons Gamal and Alaa are to be tried over the deaths of anti-government protesters in the revolution that began on 25 January.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13527102|title=Egypt: Hosni Mubarak and sons to be tried over deaths|date=24 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref> On May 28, 2011 Former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has been fined $34m (Â£20m) for cutting off communications services during the uprising that ousted him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13585237|title=Egypt: Hosni Mubarak fined for cutting internet|date=28 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref> Egypt eases blockade at Gaza's Rafah border. Women, children and men over 40 are allowed to pass freely. Men aged between 18 and 40 will still require a permit, and trade is prohibited. The crossing will now be open from 0900 to 2100 every day except Fridays and holidays. The move - strongly opposed by Israel - comes some three months after Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak lost power. Egypt and Israel closed borders with Gaza when Hamas seized power in 2007. Since then almost all Palestinians have been confined to the narrow territory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13581141|title=Egypt eases blockade at Gaza's Rafah border|date=28 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13584339|title=In pictures: Egypt-Gaza border opens at Rafah|date=28 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13240113|title=Gaza-Egypt border crossing to open permanently|date=29 April 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13552685|title=Gaza: Egypt 'to open Rafah crossing to Palestinians|date=25 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref>
+
On May 24, 2011, it was announced that Egypt's ousted President Hosni Mubarak and his two sons Gamal and Alaa are to be tried over the deaths of anti-government protesters in the revolution that began on 25 January.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13527102|title=Egypt: Hosni Mubarak and sons to be tried over deaths|date=24 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref> On May 28, 2011 Former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has been fined $34m (Â£20m) for cutting off communications services during the uprising that ousted him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13585237|title=Egypt: Hosni Mubarak fined for cutting internet|date=28 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref> Egypt eases blockade at Gaza's Rafah border. Women, children and men over 40 are allowed to pass freely. Men aged between 18 and 40 will still require a permit, and trade is prohibited. The crossing will now be open from 0900 to 2100 every day except Fridays and holidays. The move - strongly opposed by Israel - comes some three months after Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak lost power. Egypt and Israel closed borders with Gaza when Hamas seized power in 2007. Since then almost all Palestinians have been confined to the narrow territory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13581141|title=Egypt eases blockade at Gaza's Rafah border|date=28 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13584339|title=In pictures: Egypt-Gaza border opens at Rafah|date=28 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13240113|title=Gaza-Egypt border crossing to open permanently|date=29 April 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13552685|title=Gaza: Egypt 'to open Rafah crossing to Palestinians|date=25 May 2011|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=29 May 2011}}</ref>
==June==
==June==
Line 97: Line 97:
[[File:Injured Protester near Tahrir Square during the June 28.jpg|thumb|Injured Protester near Tahrir Square during the June 28.]]
[[File:Injured Protester near Tahrir Square during the June 28.jpg|thumb|Injured Protester near Tahrir Square during the June 28.]]
â
On June 6, Crowds of Egyptians dressed in black held demonstrations to honor a young man from Alexandria beaten to death a year ago in a savage attack blamed on police that helped inspire the uprising that brought down Egypt's president.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt remembers man whose death sparked revolution|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2011-06-06/world/29628236_1_large-protest-police-abuse-silent-demonstration|accessdate=1 July 2011|newspaper=SFGate.com|date=June 06, 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010, [[Khaled Said]], 28, was beaten by two plain-clothes police officers in an internet cafÃ© in Egyptâs second city, Alexandria. He was then dragged out into the street where, eyewitnesses say, the beating continued until he died.<ref>{{cite web|title=A year since Khaled Saidâs death, Egypt still waits for justice|url=http://livewire.amnesty.org/2011/06/06/a-year-since-khaled-saids-death-egypt-still-waits-for-justice/|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Pictures of his body, taken by his family in a morgue, caused public outrage that paved the way for the January 2011 uprising.<ref>{{cite web|title=A year since Khaled Saidâs death, Egypt still waits for justice|url=http://livewire.amnesty.org/2011/06/06/a-year-since-khaled-saids-death-egypt-still-waits-for-justice/|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Hundreds of protesters stood side by side on Stanley Bridge in Alexandria in a silent protest commemorating the death of Said. The protesters neither held pictures or banners of Said, they only carried the Egyptian flag. They then marched to Saidâs familyâs home in Cleopatra. By the time they arrived there, more joined to reach about 1,500. They set a big monitor on the street screening a documentary on Saeidâs case and its development.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hundreds mark anniversary of Khaled Saeid's death in Alexandria, Cairo|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/hundreds-mark-anniversary-of-khaled-saeids-death-in-alexandria-cairo.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On June 6, Crowds of Egyptians dressed in black held demonstrations to honor a young man from Alexandria beaten to death a year ago in a savage attack blamed on police that helped inspire the uprising that brought down Egypt's president.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt remembers man whose death sparked revolution|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2011-06-06/world/29628236_1_large-protest-police-abuse-silent-demonstration|accessdate=1 July 2011|newspaper=SFGate.com|date=June 06, 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010, [[Khaled Said]], 28, was beaten by two plain-clothes police officers in an internet cafÃ© in Egyptâs second city, Alexandria. He was then dragged out into the street where, eyewitnesses say, the beating continued until he died.<ref name="amnesty1">{{cite web|title=A year since Khaled Saidâs death, Egypt still waits for justice|url=http://livewire.amnesty.org/2011/06/06/a-year-since-khaled-saids-death-egypt-still-waits-for-justice/|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Pictures of his body, taken by his family in a morgue, caused public outrage that paved the way for the January 2011 uprising.<ref name="amnesty1"/> Hundreds of protesters stood side by side on Stanley Bridge in Alexandria in a silent protest commemorating the death of Said. The protesters neither held pictures or banners of Said, they only carried the Egyptian flag. They then marched to Saidâs familyâs home in Cleopatra. By the time they arrived there, more joined to reach about 1,500. They set a big monitor on the street screening a documentary on Saeidâs case and its development.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hundreds mark anniversary of Khaled Saeid's death in Alexandria, Cairo|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/hundreds-mark-anniversary-of-khaled-saeids-death-in-alexandria-cairo.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
â
On June 12, Yesterday Egypt arrested an alleged Israeli spy, Ilan Grapel.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt Accuses American of Spying for Israel|url=http://www.newser.com/story/120869/egypt-accuses-american-of-spying-for-israel.html|publisher=newser.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Egyptian officials say Grapel was sent to Egypt to build a team âtrying to gather information and data and to monitor the events of the January 25 revolution." They say Grapel tried to incite violence among Egyptian protestors, hoping to spark a face-off with the military âand spread chaos in the Egyptian public and harm the state's political, economic, and social interests.â<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt Accuses American of Spying for Israel|url=http://www.newser.com/story/120869/egypt-accuses-american-of-spying-for-israel.html|publisher=newser.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Grapel appears to be the same man who told Haaretz he moved to Israel three years before its 2006 war with Lebanon and ended up enlisting in the Israeli Defense Force. Israel, however, denies the reports. âThere is no such thing, no Israeli agent has been arrested in Egypt,â an official told the BBC. âThese reports are false.â Friends and relatives of Grapel said he is a law student in Atlanta with an avid interest in the Mideast â and not a Mossad agent out to sabotage Egyptâs revolution, as Egyptian authorities have charged. His mother said he arrived in Cairo only in May, countering implications that he was involved in protests as early as February. The arrest of 27-year-old Ilan Grapel has set off new fears in Israel that relations with Egypt will sour now that its longtime president, Hosni Mubarak, has been deposed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt spy allegations against Israeli denied by family, classmates|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-06-14/news/29657736_1_israel-and-egypt-egyptian-revolution-mossad|publisher=boston.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On June 12, Yesterday Egypt arrested an alleged Israeli spy, Ilan Grapel.<ref name="newser1">{{cite web|title=Egypt Accuses American of Spying for Israel|url=http://www.newser.com/story/120869/egypt-accuses-american-of-spying-for-israel.html|publisher=newser.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Egyptian officials say Grapel was sent to Egypt to build a team âtrying to gather information and data and to monitor the events of the January 25 revolution." They say Grapel tried to incite violence among Egyptian protestors, hoping to spark a face-off with the military âand spread chaos in the Egyptian public and harm the state's political, economic, and social interests.â<ref name="newser1"/> Grapel appears to be the same man who told Haaretz he moved to Israel three years before its 2006 war with Lebanon and ended up enlisting in the Israeli Defense Force. Israel, however, denies the reports. âThere is no such thing, no Israeli agent has been arrested in Egypt,â an official told the BBC. âThese reports are false.â Friends and relatives of Grapel said he is a law student in Atlanta with an avid interest in the Mideast â and not a Mossad agent out to sabotage Egyptâs revolution, as Egyptian authorities have charged. His mother said he arrived in Cairo only in May, countering implications that he was involved in protests as early as February. The arrest of 27-year-old Ilan Grapel has set off new fears in Israel that relations with Egypt will sour now that its longtime president, Hosni Mubarak, has been deposed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt spy allegations against Israeli denied by family, classmates|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-06-14/news/29657736_1_israel-and-egypt-egyptian-revolution-mossad|publisher=boston.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
â
On June 19, The military prosecution released on Sunday editor-in-chief of Al-Fagr tabloid Adel Hammouda and journalist Rasha Azab without bail pending further investigations. They were both interrogated on charges of publishing false news that disturb the public peace and negligence in the editorial process. Hammouda was released at around 1 pm, while Azab was released later at around 4:30 pm after which she immediately led chants of âdown with military rule.â<ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Fagr journalists released pending further investigations|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/al-fagr-journalist-released-pending-further-investigations-dp1.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Azab had written an article published earlier last week about a meeting between SCAF and prominent members of an advocacy group against military trials for civilians called âNo to Military Trialsâ. Group members showed SCAF proof and evidence of the militaryâs violations against civilians, according to Azabâs article. Azab said that Major General Hassan El-Roweiny was astonished when he saw the pictures and testimonies demonstrating the armyâs violations. She added that El-Roweiny apologized to one of the female witnesses for being violated in military prison, adding that individual actions donât represent the morals or principles of the army.<ref>{{cite web|title=Al-Fagr journalists released pending further investigations|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/al-fagr-journalist-released-pending-further-investigations-dp1.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On June 19, The military prosecution released on Sunday editor-in-chief of Al-Fagr tabloid Adel Hammouda and journalist Rasha Azab without bail pending further investigations. They were both interrogated on charges of publishing false news that disturb the public peace and negligence in the editorial process. Hammouda was released at around 1 pm, while Azab was released later at around 4:30 pm after which she immediately led chants of âdown with military rule.â<ref name="thedailynewsegyptcivil">{{cite web|title=Al-Fagr journalists released pending further investigations|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/al-fagr-journalist-released-pending-further-investigations-dp1.html|publisher=thedailynewsegypt.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> Azab had written an article published earlier last week about a meeting between SCAF and prominent members of an advocacy group against military trials for civilians called âNo to Military Trialsâ. Group members showed SCAF proof and evidence of the militaryâs violations against civilians, according to Azabâs article. Azab said that Major General Hassan El-Roweiny was astonished when he saw the pictures and testimonies demonstrating the armyâs violations. She added that El-Roweiny apologized to one of the female witnesses for being violated in military prison, adding that individual actions donât represent the morals or principles of the army.<ref name="thedailynewsegyptcivil"/>
On June 20, Mubarak's lawyer, Farid el-Deeb, said the ousted president underwent "critical surgery" in Heidelberg, Germany, in 2010 to remove his gallbladder and part of his pancreas, which were cancerous. "There is evidence suggesting that there is a recurrence of cancer and that it has reached the stomach," el-Deeb told The Associated Press. He called Mubarak's condition "horrible" and said the former leader "doesn't eat and he loses consciousness quite often." Mubarak is in the hospital in Sharm el-Sheikh, the Red Sea resort where he has been living since his ouster.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lawyer says Egypt's Mubarak may have cancer|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Lawyer-says-Egypt-s-Mubarak-may-have-cancer-1429973.php|publisher=seattlepi.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
On June 20, Mubarak's lawyer, Farid el-Deeb, said the ousted president underwent "critical surgery" in Heidelberg, Germany, in 2010 to remove his gallbladder and part of his pancreas, which were cancerous. "There is evidence suggesting that there is a recurrence of cancer and that it has reached the stomach," el-Deeb told The Associated Press. He called Mubarak's condition "horrible" and said the former leader "doesn't eat and he loses consciousness quite often." Mubarak is in the hospital in Sharm el-Sheikh, the Red Sea resort where he has been living since his ouster.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lawyer says Egypt's Mubarak may have cancer|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Lawyer-says-Egypt-s-Mubarak-may-have-cancer-1429973.php|publisher=seattlepi.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
Line 107: Line 107:
On June 21, Egypt's military rulers launched an online poll to test the popularity of potential presidential candidates, a move analysts said may be aimed at judging public appetite for getting a former officer back in the post. The list on Facebook includes at least four ex-military officers, alongside Islamists, judges, diplomats and others. Most have declared they will run, including two former officers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptian army tests political winds|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Egyptian+army+tests+political+winds/4978519/story.html|publisher=http://www.montrealgazette.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
On June 21, Egypt's military rulers launched an online poll to test the popularity of potential presidential candidates, a move analysts said may be aimed at judging public appetite for getting a former officer back in the post. The list on Facebook includes at least four ex-military officers, alongside Islamists, judges, diplomats and others. Most have declared they will run, including two former officers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptian army tests political winds|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Egyptian+army+tests+political+winds/4978519/story.html|publisher=http://www.montrealgazette.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
â
On June 22, Egypt's Cabinet approved a budget for fiscal 2011-2012, boosting spending in social programs to meet growing demands from the people after the uprising that ousted former President Hosni Mubarak. The budget totals 490.6 billion pound ($83 billion), reflecting a spending increase of 14.7 percent over the current fiscal year, while revenues are forecast at $59 billion. <ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt approves $83B budget, boosts social spending|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/nation/egypt-approves-83b-budget-boosts-social-spending-1.2976811|publisher=newsday.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> On the same day, Leaders of the youth wing of Egyptâs Muslim Brotherhood have split with their elders to form an independent political party, deepening the fractures within the group as some of its prominent members move toward a more centrist and liberal version of Islamist politics. The new group, the [[Egyptian Current Party]], is expected to advocate the separation of religion from politics, the protection of individual freedoms and the embrace of Islamic morals and culture without the enforcement of Islamic religious law. Its founders, including Islam Lotfy, Mohamed el-Kasaas and Mohamed Abbas, were among the young leaders of the Egyptian revolution and broke with the Brotherhood to help lead the first day of the protests that brought down former President Hosni Mubarak.<ref>{{cite web|title=In Egypt, Youth Wing Breaks From Muslim Brotherhood|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/23/world/middleeast/23egypt.html|publisher=http://www.nytimes.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On June 22, Egypt's Cabinet approved a budget for fiscal 2011-2012, boosting spending in social programs to meet growing demands from the people after the uprising that ousted former President Hosni Mubarak. The budget totals 490.6 billion pound ($83 billion), reflecting a spending increase of 14.7 percent over the current fiscal year, while revenues are forecast at $59 billion. <ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt approves $83B budget, boosts social spending|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/nation/egypt-approves-83b-budget-boosts-social-spending-1.2976811|publisher=newsday.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> On the same day, Leaders of the youth wing of Egyptâs Muslim Brotherhood have split with their elders to form an independent political party, deepening the fractures within the group as some of its prominent members move toward a more centrist and liberal version of Islamist politics. The new group, the [[Egyptian Current Party]], is expected to advocate the separation of religion from politics, the protection of individual freedoms and the embrace of Islamic morals and culture without the enforcement of Islamic religious law. Its founders, including Islam Lotfy, Mohamed el-Kasaas and Mohamed Abbas, were among the young leaders of the Egyptian revolution and broke with the Brotherhood to help lead the first day of the protests that brought down former President Hosni Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|title=In Egypt, Youth Wing Breaks From Muslim Brotherhood|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/23/world/middleeast/23egypt.html|publisher=http://www.nytimes.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
On June 26th, John McCain, R-Arizona and John Kerry, D-Massachusetts, visiting Egypt at the head of a U.S. business delegation, said it was in Americaâs national security interests to see the uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak succeed. They said Washington was not interested in dictating policy to Egypt. Instead, the focus is on finding ways to help the Arab worldâs most populous nation boost its economy and address the needs of its people.<ref>{{cite web|title=McCain: Egypt military wants civilian government|url=http://www.longislandpress.com/2011/06/26/mccain-egypt-military-wants-civilian-government/|publisher=http://www.longislandpress.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
On June 26th, John McCain, R-Arizona and John Kerry, D-Massachusetts, visiting Egypt at the head of a U.S. business delegation, said it was in Americaâs national security interests to see the uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak succeed. They said Washington was not interested in dictating policy to Egypt. Instead, the focus is on finding ways to help the Arab worldâs most populous nation boost its economy and address the needs of its people.<ref>{{cite web|title=McCain: Egypt military wants civilian government|url=http://www.longislandpress.com/2011/06/26/mccain-egypt-military-wants-civilian-government/|publisher=http://www.longislandpress.com|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
Line 115: Line 115:
==July==
==July==
â
The '''"Friday of Retribution"'''; Tens of thousands of demonstrators filled Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to voice frustration with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they called the slow pace of change five months after the revolution<ref>http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/</ref>.
+
The '''"Friday of Retribution"'''; Tens of thousands of demonstrators filled Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to voice frustration with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they called the slow pace of change five months after the revolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref>
